text: Hi, I’m Francis,
the host of this show "Cooking with Dog."
Today, we will be making shaved ice with fresh, seasonal watermelon.
When frozen, you will be able to enjoy a slightly different flavor and texture.
First, let’s make the syrup.
Combine the water and sugar in a pot.
Turn on the burner
and dissolve the sugar.
When it begins to boil, turn the heat to low.
And reduce the syrup for 2 to 3 minutes.
Then, pour it into a pitcher and let it sit to cool.
You can adjust the amount of sugar to taste.
Now, let’s make the watermelon puree.
You will be using the rind as a plate
so cut off both ends of the wedge.
Then, slice off the flesh and place it onto a tray.
Make sure to remove the seeds.
If you are a smart or lazy person,
use a seedless watermelon instead.
Finally, trim off the top of the rind.
Now, place the watermelon into a bowl.
Add about half of the syrup.
And crush the flesh with a balloon whisk.
Watermelon will help to combat the heat
and relieve your fatigue
so it is a great fruit for summer dessert.
Then, place the puree into an ice mold.
Place the mold in the freezer for over half a day
to freeze it completely.
Chill the rind in the fridge or freezer
to help avoid melting the ice.
And now, let’s make the watermelon kakigori
with the shaved ice maker.
Place the frozen puree into the work bowl
and cover.
The puree takes a longer time to freeze completely
since the extra sugar was added.
Then, shave the watermelon onto the chilled rind.
Occasionally adjust the shape
and continue to shave the watermelon.
Finally, top with the chocolate chips
that represent watermelon seeds.
Now, it is ready to serve.
The condensed milk goes great with watermelon
so drizzle it over when the kakigori isn’t sweet enough.
Adding the syrup to the puree means that
you don't have to pour more over the ice
so its easy to make a pretty shape.
The crunchy chocolate in the fluffy ice gives the kakigori a pleasant texture.
We found out shaved ice is popular all around the world.
Please let us know your favorite type of
ice dessert in the comments!
Good luck in the kitchen!
